article_title: Despite bipartisan howls, medical-device tax persists
article_text:
LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) — It’s the tax that few in Congress seem to want, but no one is sure when, or if it will be repealed.

The medical-device tax woven into President Obama’s health-care overhaul in 2010 seems to endure even though few lawmakers see its value and the industry is lobbying intensely to kill it, surviving a near-miss in October when lawmakers nearly squelched it but weren’t able as it got caught in the vortex of a bruising government shutdown.

Bloomberg The logo of Medtronic Inc. is displayed at Medtronic Singapore Operations.

Regardless of support on both sides of the aisle, from even the likes of the most liberal stalwarts in the Senate such as Al Franken of Minnesota and Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts as well as 41 House Democrats, a repeal measure has yet to weave its way through the legislative process.

But there’s no guarantee that it will be repealed. Even its most ardent supporters aren’t sure because it takes out $30 billion out of the Obamacare program with no replacement funding earmarked. Still, supporters of rolling back the tariff press on.

“I believe there is momentum building to address the tax,” said Rep. Charlie Dent, a Pennsylvania Republican who is sponsoring one of several bills designed to repeal it. “I can’t forecast timing, but there’s a real shot.”

The medical-device tax has upset the apple cart for what has been a thriving sector within the health-care industry over the past decade and a half. Since the century’s turn, makers of stents, artificial limbs, pacemakers and surgical gear have thrived.

Profits have flourished for the largest companies in the sector such as Medtronic Inc. MDT, +0.65% , St. Jude Medical Inc. STJ, +0.50% and Stryker Corp. SYK, +1.17% , with net margins doubling in some cases. Last fiscal year, industry leader Medtronic saw its net profit margin exceed 20%, putting it on par with that of pharmaceutical giants. For companies like Medtronic, a company that enjoys margins that are quadruple that of most companies, the 2.3% tax on revenue may seem miniscule.

Yet companies in the sector see stagnation with the tax as well as growing pressure to keep costs down in all parts of the medical business. Firms that projected smooth sailing just a few years ago are concerned those enviable profits will erode. For smaller companies that don’t have near the same margins, many worry they’ll be dead in the water before long.

It’s unclear how the tax was included in the Affordable Care Act in the first place – some believe it was an industry giveback developed specifically for device makers while others believe the ballooning margins on big players in this sector may have played a role.

But thousands of smaller device makers say the tariff would eat up most of their profits, if they have any, since it’s a tax on sales and not just profits.

“We’re actually borrowing money to pay the excise tax,” said Tom Allen, chief executive of Iconacy Orthopedic Patients, a 13-employee start-up that makes orthopedic devices.

Iconacy is based in Warsaw, Ind., a small town about 40 miles west of Fort Wayne. Warsaw has become a nexus of sorts for dozens of small device makers, and a few large so-called “med tech” companies such as privately held Biomet Inc.

Economic development officials in the region are concerned the tax will stifle the development of other companies in the burgeoning region. Other executives have trouble understanding how their industry could be targeted for an excise tax, which they say was a sloppy attempt to get med techs to contribute to Obamacare. Other means were used to get biopharmaceutical companies and their 20%-plus margins to contribute, but the device tax is seen as a more inelegant approach.

“I think of an excise tax as being for cigarettes or liquor, not on a maker of surgical implants for kids,” said Mark Throdahl, chief executive of OrthoPediatrics, also based in Warsaw. As its name indicates, the firm makes devices geared specifically for children.

Throdahl says if the tax were a tariff on income, it might be understandable – and more manageable for medical device makers. But all med techs are being hit with the same tax on sales, regardless of size or ability to turn a profit.

“It just seems perverse,” he said. “We’re being held hostage to some political process in Washington. I think this is outrageous.”

The sentiment is just as passionate nine hours northwest of Warsaw, in Minneapolis, which is home to Medtronic and 400 other device companies that employ roughly 35,000 people. The region is second only to California in number of med techs but first in concentration of firms with double the average of other metro areas.

Now, however, there is concern that growth may be stunted, even stifled, if the tax persists. Locals say they’re already seeing the effects of it.

“Investment in med tech has just cratered. It’s at an all-time low,” said Shaye Mandle, executive vice president and chief operating officer of the trade group LifeScience Alley. He says there had been a drop in investment in recent years, but the tax “put a cherry on top” of that trend.

Now he worries it will take too long to come out of it, with the tax looming overhead for prospective proprietors and investors.

“If investment continues to be at this level, which is non-existent, you won’t see a lot of companies,” he said.

One glaring example of the tax’s effect came from Kalamazoo, Mich.-based Stryker, which said in late 2012 that it would have to cut its workforce by nearly 1,200, due largely to the Obamacare excise tax. That reduction came even though Jon Stryker, grandson of the company’s founder, has been a staunch Obama supporter.

J.C. Scott, chief lobbyist for the Advanced Medical Technology Association, the industry’s trade group, says some companies are cutting back on research and development -- the life’s blood for many companies in the industry. Others are going so far as to cut back on 401K matches, he said.

“You’re seeing it happen in a number of different ways,” Scott said.

How might the tax get repealed? Rep. Dent’s effort is part of a larger bill that seeks to strike a deal with Democrats over the tax and several other related – and unrelated – issues. Dent offers to extend unemployment benefits in exchange for repealing the tax, changing the definition of full-time workers as defined under Obamacare from 30 hours a week to 40 hours, and approving the controversial Keystone oil pipeline from Canada down through the middle of the U.S. to the Gulf of Mexico.

Gaining consensus on this hodgepodge of issues may be too tall a task for this contentious Congress. Dent says repealing the tax, however, is a high priority.

“We’re going to keep at it. If we can’t repeal it [here] we’ll try it some other way,” he said. “It’s a job killer. It raises costs and it stifles innovation.”

One potential problem is that attaching a repeal of the tax to other measures isn’t popular with Senate Democrats, and in particular Majority Leader Harry Reid. When attempts were made to attach a repeal of the tax to measures that would have put the government back in business during its October shutdown, Reid nixed the idea as “stupid.”

White House spokesman Jay Carney also said at the time that Obama would not sign a stopgap bill with a repeal of the medical-device tax attached to it.

Still, there is a clear majority in the Senate that is opposed to the tax. Senators voted 79-20 last year to repeal the tax in non-binding resolution. Yet that points out another roadblock to a repeal – the resolution was non-binding because no solution on how to make up the $30 billion in lost Obamacare revenue has been found.

Rep. Erik Paulsen, a Minnesota Republican still is trying to get his legislation pushed through, nearly a year after introducing it on Feb. 6. Paulsen aides say the bill, H.R. 523, has 269 co-sponsors, including 41 Democrats.

“The Congressman is still 100% committed to repealing the device tax and is actively pushing this legislation forward,” Stacey Johnson, Paulsen’s deputy chief of staff, said in an e-mail.
